oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Effect of seed treatment with acetic acid in control of seed borne diseases
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Borgen, Anders
Nielsen, Bent
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Post harvest management and techniques
Crop health, quality, protection
Breeding, genetics and propagation
Cereals, pulses and oilseeds
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In field trials, seed treatment with acetic acid has reduced common bunt (Tilletia tritici) in winter wheat by 91.5-96.2% and by 83% in spring wheat without negative effects on germination vigour of the seeds. Leaf stripe (Pyrenophora graminea) in spring barley was reduced by 93,4%. Acetic acid is a cheap and environmental friendly fungicide with a possible scope of application especially in organic agriculture, where conventional pesticides are prohibited.
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Borgen, Anders and Nielsen, Bent (2001) Effect of seed treatment with acetic acid in control of seed borne diseases. In: Biddle, A.J. (Ed.) Proceedings of the BCPC Symposium No. 76: “Seed Treatment: Challenges & Opportunities”, Farnham, 76, British Crop Protection Council, no. 76.
